title: 113_s681
content: The "Offshore Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Offshore Fairness Act" defines key terms such as coast line, existing interest, expanded seaward boundary, and expanded submerged land. The "Offshore Fairness Act" defines key terms including expanded submerged land, interest owner, Secretary, and State. The "Offshore Fairness Act" defines key terms including expanded submerged land, interest owner, Secretary, and State. SEC. 3. SEAWARD BOUNDARIES OF CERTAIN STATES. The Offshore Fairness Act amends the Submerged Lands Act to establish seaward boundaries for certain coastal states, including Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia. The boundaries are set at 3 marine leagues from the coast line of each state. The Submerged Lands Act is amended to establish seaward boundaries for certain coastal states, including Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia, at 3 marine leagues from the coast line. Amendments include specifying distances from the coast line of states described in section 4(b). The Submerged Lands Act is amended to establish seaward boundaries for certain coastal states at 3 marine leagues from the coast line. Amendments include specifying distances from the coast line of states described in section 4(b). SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE. The Secretary must notify states of their right to request conveyance of submerged land within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Upon request, the Secretary will transfer authority to the Governor of the State, with the condition that state requirements for interest owners must not be stricter than federal law. The State must agree to indemnify the United States for any liability related to the conveyance of submerged land and administration of existing interests. SEC. 5. EFFECT. The Act and its amendments do not impact existing rights to expanded submerged land. Submerged land within a State's seaward boundaries is subject to Federal oil and gas mineral rights, considered part of the Federal outer Continental Shelf, and subject to leasing and revenue distribution laws. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 does not affect existing Federal oil and gas leases. If a lease is divided due to conveyance, the new portion will not take effect until the original lease expires. This section does not apply to future interests granted by the State in expanded submerged land. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 allows States to tax within their seaward boundaries, excluding existing Federal oil and gas leases. Federal leases remain taxable by the State. SEC. 6. FISHERY MANAGEMENT RIGHTS. The Secretary of Commerce grants each State exclusive fishery management authority over reef fish in the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean in expanded submerged land. Additionally, each State is granted temporary exclusive fishery management authority over red snapper fish in specific areas of the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean. The Governor of a State must certify to the Secretary of Commerce in writing that they are confident in the accuracy and scientific basis of stock assessments for red snapper fish within the State's authority granted by the Act.
